channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [TIKA-3833] bzip2 MIME type is detected as bzip instead when using tika-core
item.description:
Hello, I'm having a bit of a problem when using the tika-core module (v2.4.1).
I am trying to detect the MIME type of a bzip2 file and, instead of
application/x-bzip2, I am getting application/x-bzip. I believe it has
something to do with the mime-type definitions in the
tika-mimetypes.xml file.

<mime-type type="application/x-bzip">
  <magic priority="40">
    <match value="BZh" type="string" offset="0"/>
  </magic>
  <glob pattern="*.bz"/>
  <glob pattern="*.tbz"/>
</mime-type>
<mime-type type="application/x-bzip2">
  <sub-class-of type="application/x-bzip"/>
  <_comment>Bzip 2 UNIX Compressed File</_comment>
  <magic priority="40">
    <match value="\x42\x5a\x68\x39\x31" type="string" offset="0"/>
  </magic>
  <glob pattern="*.bz2"/>
  <glob pattern="*.tbz2"/>
  <glob pattern="*.boz"/>
</mime-type>

The priority for these is set to 40, I believe that the priority of
application/x-bzip2 should be higher, because string value "BZh" and
hex value part "\x42\x5a\x68" are equal. x42\x5a\x68 = BZh.

Maybe I am missing something here? Does this look like a bug or this
works as intended? Maybe I can provide some sort of hint for the
default detector?

A small example in Scala:

import org.apache.tika.config.TikaConfig
import org.apache.tika.detect.DefaultProbDetector
import org.apache.tika.metadata.{Metadata, TikaCoreProperties}

import java.io.{BufferedInputStream, File, FileInputStream}

object AAA {
  def main(args: Array[String]): Unit = {
    val config = TikaConfig.getDefaultConfig

    val file = new File("/home/ekazakas/test.csv.bz2")
    val detector = new DefaultProbDetector()
    val mediaType = detector.detect(new BufferedInputStream(new FileInputStream(file)), new Metadata)
    val mimeType = config.getMimeRepository.forName(mediaType.toString)
    println(mimeType)
  }
}

This prints `application/x-bzip` instead of `application/x-bzip2`.
item.summary: bzip2 MIME type is detected as bzip instead when using tika-core

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Thank you for reporting this and opening this issue. Y. That looks like a bug. Are you able to share a small example file for unit tests?
I have a test file. I'll take a look at this early tomorrow.
Thank you tallison , let me know if I can be more of assistance here.

I bumped the priority just now for bz2 and added a test file and unit tests for the DefaultDetector.

As a side note, before I made any changes, I was not able to reproduce bz detection on my example bz2 file with either the DefaultDetector or the DefaultProbDetector. I can't explain why you were getting bz detection in Scala, and I wasn't getting that in Java...given that we were both not including the filename in the Metadata.

tallison I have attached a small test application. Interesting enough, when this works with default bzip2 compression level, it is able to detect the application/x-bzip2 correctly, but if I try to change the compression level, it falls back to application/x-bzip.

The attached archive contains several bzip2 files produced using bzip2 and lbzip2 commands on Ubuntu.

- bzip2 -z test-file-1.csv
- lbzip2 -z test-file-2.csv
- bzip2 -z empty-file.csv
- bzip2 -z small-file.csv
- lbzip2 -8 -z lbzip2-8-file.csv
- bzip2 -8 -z bzip2-8-file.csv

the hexdump of the archives that were generated using default compression level shows this "header":

0000000 5a42 3968

while the hexdump of the archives that were generated using compression level = 8, returns this:

0000000 5a42 3868 

I have also tried to compress some random text file and gave it compression level = 3, this was the hexdump:

0000000 5a42 3368

So I assume that the numbers 39, 38 and 33 (these are 9, 8 and 3 in ASCII) reflect the compression level of the bzip2 file and that means that the priority fix won't solve our issue. I believe the magic string should be modified or additional magic strings should be added for correct matching and taking this compression level number into account.

Y, agreed. Thank you for sharing the example files. I'm able to replicate this now with your repo and in tika-core.

When I added the unit tests to tika-parsers-standard-package, that brought in the DefaultZipContainerDetector which in turn relies on detection from commons-compress. That bypasses the mime detection you pointed out. So, for those using tika-app and tika-server, this isn't a problem.

However, I agree that we need to fix our mimetypes definitions.

Your examples are super useful. Thank you.

Looks like bzip1 starts with "BZ0", and bzip2 starts with "BZh[1-9]". Commons-compress only relies on BZh. I was really hoping we could also require the mime "0x314159265359" because of its beauty, but that isn't used in your zero byte example.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bzip2

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build Tika » tika-main-jdk8 #736 (See https://ci-builds.apache.org/job/Tika/job/tika-main-jdk8/736/)
TIKA-3833 – bump priority for bz2 slightly (tallison: https://github.com/apache/tika/commit/67b2c368fe28cc2b2a4e13d5065db6877c26d1be)

  • (edit) tika-core/src/main/resources/org/apache/tika/mime/tika-mimetypes.xml
  • (add) tika-parsers/tika-parsers-standard/tika-parsers-standard-modules/tika-parser-pkg-module/src/test/resources/test-documents/test-bz2.txt.bz2
  • (edit) tika-parsers/tika-parsers-standard/tika-parsers-standard-package/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/mime/TestMimeTypes.java

Just pushed the updates and added your example files to a unit test in tika-core.

On your test example:

application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
====================================
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
====================================
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
application/x-bzip2
Great. I see that the priority change is in place, do you plan to add the fix for the correct magic strings as well?

SUCCESS: Integrated in Jenkins build Tika » tika-main-jdk8 #737 (See https://ci-builds.apache.org/job/Tika/job/tika-main-jdk8/737/)
TIKA-3833 – improve mime type detection for bz2 files. (tallison: https://github.com/apache/tika/commit/e32c174effb70e30b7800905f1e86d8efe4dcbec)

  • (add) tika-core/src/test/resources/test-documents/bz2/small-file.txt.bz2
  • (edit) tika-core/src/test/java/org/apache/tika/detect/MagicDetectorTest.java
  • (add) tika-core/src/test/resources/test-documents/bz2/bzip2-8-file.txt.bz2
  • (add) tika-core/src/test/resources/test-documents/bz2/test-file-1.csv.bz2
  • (add) tika-core/src/test/resources/test-documents/bz2/lbzip2-8-file.txt.bz2
  • (edit) tika-core/src/main/resources/org/apache/tika/mime/tika-mimetypes.xml
  • (add) tika-core/src/test/resources/test-documents/bz2/empty-file.txt.bz2
  • (add) tika-core/src/test/resources/test-documents/bz2/test-file-2.csv.bz2

Those should be in there?

https://github.com/apache/tika/commit/e32c174effb70e30b7800905f1e86d8efe4dcbec

yeah, I see it now, I haven't seen the message from Hudson at that time. Thank you for the quick solution. Maybe you know when this is going to be released? I assume this will be included in the next release version, correct?
Lazy consensus so far may have the next release process starting Aug 29th. Haven't heard any objections yet on the dev list.
Great, I assume we can close this issue, since it seems to be resolved.
Y. Thank you for opening this and supplying the test cases and example files!
